body.p: Mrs Banks has procured the signatures of a majority of the Jury who tried her husband & McClure, this you will see from the petition & the certificate of the clerk of the Jeff. Circuit Court. C. Henry Finck the owner of the tobacco & Baumberger the man who bought the tobacco unite in the prayer for a pardon. You will discover many good names signed to the petition.

Mrs banks takes with her a letter from the officer of Banks' Reg in which they "say he is a man of good character: they would have written the same for McClure had they be applied too for that purpose. I learn from the officers that they are both good men & have been good soldiers. I do hope & pray you will grant them a full pardon.
Those of the Jury would have signed the petition but are absent from the city

Louisville Feby 9th 1864
His Excellency
T. E. Bramlette
Dr Sir.

The two men Banks & McClure who were sometime since brought before me charged with Larceny, I understand belong to the army or have served a Tour of duty Each & have been regarded as good Soldiers & faithful to their country. The Two men Fincks & Baumberger who alone suffered by their acts have signed their Petition for a Pardon. Indeed their seems to be a general wish with those acquainted with the circumstances & the history of the two men for the past two or three years, that they should be Pardoned & I admit that I feel the same wish that they should be released

Very Respectfully
Your obt Servt
Geo. W. Johnston.
